chatgpt_double_star.new_statement: Abortion laws should be built around protecting human dignity and patient safety, using clear medical standards that let clinicians act quickly in emergencies and avoid criminalizing good-faith care. Where limits are set, they should be tied to fetal development and viability, paired with explicit exceptions for threats to life or serious health, pregnancies from sexual violence, and diagnoses incompatible with survival, with transparent review processes that do not delay treatment. At the same time, governments should reduce the need for abortion by expanding contraception access, medically accurate education, and real supports for pregnancy, parenting, and adoption so choices are less constrained by crisis or poverty.

chatgpt_double_star_rankings.new_statement: Abortion laws should be guided by compassion and sound medical evidence, respecting the moral seriousness many attach to developing life while protecting the health, autonomy, and privacy of the pregnant person. Rules should be clear and workable for clinicians, guaranteeing timely care and narrowly defined exceptions for serious threats to life or health, rape or incest, and nonviable or fatal fetal conditions. To reduce abortions and hardship, policy should prioritize prevention and practical supports—affordable contraception, comprehensive sex education, prenatal care, childcare, adoption services, and economic assistance—so fewer families face crisis decisions.

chatgpt_double_star_personas.new_statement: Abortion laws should reflect both the moral value many place on unborn life and the dignity, health, and freedom of the pregnant person by using clear, medically evidence-based standards and preserving timely care guided by patients and licensed clinicians. Any limits should include explicit, workable exceptions for threats to life or serious health, rape or incest, and nonviable or fatal fetal conditions, written so doctors can act without fear or delay. Common ground also means reducing abortions through prevention and support—affordable contraception, responsible sex education, prenatal care, adoption options, and practical help for parents—so families have real choices rather than crisis-driven ones.
